title: What does it mean to be a refugee? - Benedetta Berti and Evelien Borgman

multiple-choice.question: According to the UN's 1951 Convention, what is the definition of a refugee?

options.label: A
options.text: Someone who is outside their country of nationality and is unable to return due to economic hardship.

options.label: B
options.text: Someone who is outside their country of nationality and is unable to return due to well-founded fears of being persecuted.

options.label: C
options.text: Someone who is inside their country of nationality and is unable to leave due to persecution.

options.label: D
options.text: Someone who is outside their country of nationality and is unable to return due to natural disasters.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between a migrant and a refugee?

options.label: A
options.text: A migrant is someone who leaves their country for better economic opportunities, while a refugee is someone who leaves due to persecution.

options.label: B
options.text: A migrant is someone who leaves their country due to persecution, while a refugee is someone who leaves for better economic opportunities.

options.label: C
options.text: A migrant is someone who leaves their country temporarily, while a refugee is someone who leaves permanently.

options.label: D
options.text: A migrant is someone who leaves their country with proper documents, while a refugee is someone who leaves without proper documents.

multiple-choice.question: What is the most basic obligation of a host country towards refugees?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide them with employment opportunities.

options.label: B
options.text: To provide them with education and healthcare.

options.label: C
options.text: To guarantee a minimum standard of treatment and non-discrimination.

options.label: D
options.text: To ensure their safe return to their home country.

multiple-choice.question: What is the principle of non-refoulement?

options.label: A
options.text: The principle of sending an individual to a country where their life and freedom are threatened.

options.label: B
options.text: The principle of not sending an individual to a country where their life and freedom are threatened.

options.label: C
options.text: The principle of providing an individual with employment opportunities in a host country.

options.label: D
options.text: The principle of providing an individual with education and healthcare in a host country.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the current situation of many refugee children?

options.label: A
options.text: Many refugee children are able to attend school and receive proper education.

options.label: B
options.text: Many refugee children are out of school due to lack of funding for education programs.

options.label: C
options.text: Many refugee children are able to find employment and support themselves.

options.label: D
options.text: Many refugee children are able to reunite with their families quickly.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the United Nations Refugee Agency in refugee camps?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide refugees with employment opportunities.

options.label: B
options.text: To provide refugees with education and healthcare.

options.label: C
options.text: To run the refugee camps and provide short-term shelter to refugees.

options.label: D
options.text: To ensure the safe return of refugees to their home country.

multiple-choice.question: What is the first legal step for a displaced person in a new country?
According to the transcript, how many people are currently displaced worldwide?
What is the difference between an asylum seeker and a refugee?

options.label: A
options.text: An asylum seeker is someone who has been recognized as a refugee, while a refugee is someone who is still seeking asylum.

options.label: B
options.text: An asylum seeker is someone who is seeking asylum, but has not yet been recognized as a refugee, while a refugee is someone who has been recognized as such.

options.label: C
options.text: An asylum seeker is someone who is fleeing persecution, while a refugee is someone who is fleeing economic hardship.

options.label: D
options.text: An asylum seeker is someone who is seeking asylum in their home country, while a refugee is someone who is seeking asylum in a foreign country.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the current situation of many refugees in terms of their ability to enter the workforce?

options.label: A
options.text: Many refugees are able to enter the workforce and support themselves.

options.label: B
options.text: Many refugees are not permitted to enter the workforce and are fully dependent on humanitarian aid.

options.label: C
options.text: Many refugees are able to find employment, but are not paid a fair wage.

options.label: D
options.text: Many refugees are able to start their own businesses and become entrepreneurs.

title: The evolution of the book - Julie Dreyfuss

multiple-choice.question: What is considered the earliest object to be thought of as a book?

options.label: B
options.text: A stack of papers tied with a string

options.text: A codex, a stack of pages bound along one edge

options.label: B
options.text: Because water-based ink was not durable

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: C
options.text: To make the book more durable

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: A rounded spine makes the book easier to read

options.label: C
options.text: A rounded spine makes the book more durable

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Are You A Good Listener?

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the most important life skills that few people possess?

options.label: B
options.text: Because no one has taught them how to listen

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are too busy speaking

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not interested in others

multiple-choice.question: What is one thing that a good listener does to make conversation more enjoyable?

options.label: A
options.text: They interrupt the speaker to share their own thoughts

options.label: B
options.text: They egg the speaker on and encourage them to elaborate

options.label: C
options.text: They change the subject to something more interesting

options.label: A
options.text: It helps the speaker to clarify their thoughts

options.label: B
options.text: It helps the listener to understand the speaker's perspective

options.label: C
options.text: It helps to change the subject

options.label: D
options.text: It helps to end the conversation

options.label: B
options.text: They refer back to something the speaker said earlier

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of a good listener when they urge clarification?

options.label: B
options.text: To understand the speaker's underlying attitudes

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is one thing that a good listener does not do?

options.label: A
options.text: They do not interrupt the speaker

multiple-choice.question: How does a good listener make the speaker feel when they are vulnerable?

options.label: A
options.text: They avoid disagreeing with the speaker

options.label: B
options.text: They make it clear that they can like the speaker and still disagree with them

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: They end the conversation when they disagree

title: The microbial jungles all over the place (and you) - Scott Chimileski and Roberto Kolter

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the vast communities of microbes that gather by the millions?
What type of organisms are typically found in natural biofilms?

options.label: C
options.text: A variety of microbes, including bacteria, archaea, algae, fungi, and protozoa

options.label: D
options.text: No microbes are found in natural biofilms

options.label: A
options.text: Using their flagella to propel themselves

options.label: B
options.text: Using sticky appendages to attach to the surface

options.label: C
options.text: Using the extracellular matrix to hold themselves in place

options.label: D
options.text: Using a combination of flagella and sticky appendages

multiple-choice.question: What is the main advantage of microbes living in a biofilm compared to living alone?

options.label: B
options.text: Improved safety due to the extracellular matrix

options.label: C
options.text: Enhanced ability to communicate and cooperate with other cells

options.label: A
options.text: By secreting chemicals into the environment

options.label: B
options.text: By deploying molecular spears to inject nearby cells with toxins

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the benefits that microbial communities provide to humans and other species?
What is an example of a food that contains a biofilm that is considered normal and flavor-enhancing?
Why are microbial communities important to the global ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: They produce much of the oxygen we breathe

options.label: B
options.text: They are recruited to clean up environmental pollution

options.label: C
options.text: They play a critical role in supporting all larger organisms, including humans

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: To test the boys' physical endurance and resilience

options.label: D
options.text: To celebrate the arts and music

options.text: It was a phrase used to promote physical perfection

options.label: D
options.text: It was a phrase used to promote the arts and music

options.label: B

options.text: To bear children that would one day become strong and capable warriors

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Only men who died in battle

options.label: D
options.text: Only women who died in childbirth

options.label: A

title: Can wildlife adapt to climate change? - Erin Eastwood

multiple-choice.question: What is one way humans can adapt to climate change?

options.label: B
options.text: By using technological advancements to find solutions

options.label: C
options.text: By relocating themselves to different climates

multiple-choice.question: What is the typical time scale for evolutionary adaptation to occur?

options.label: B
options.text: Thousands to hundreds of thousands of years

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a non-heritable change to an individual's physical traits?

options.label: A
options.text: A change in the color of a bird's plumage due to genetic variation

options.label: B
options.text: A change in the size of an animal's body due to environmental factors

options.label: C
options.text: A change in the date of flowering or breeding due to climate change

options.label: D
options.text: A change in the shape of a plant's leaves due to genetic mutation

multiple-choice.question: Why are scientists seeking examples of evolutionary changes coded in species' DNA?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand the mechanisms of climate change

options.label: B
options.text: To identify species that are most vulnerable to extinction

options.label: C
options.text: To find a key to the future survival of species

options.label: D
options.text: To study the evolution of new species

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason for the shift in the color variant of the tawny owl population?

options.label: A
options.text: The brown color variant is more attractive to mates

options.label: B
options.text: The gray color variant is more resistant to disease

options.label: C
options.text: The brown color variant has a selective advantage in exposed forests

options.label: D
options.text: The gray color variant is more common in the population

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following species has adapted to warmer temperatures by entering dormancy later in the year?
What is the reason for the shift in the color combination of the two spot ladybug population?

options.label: A
options.text: The non-melanic color combination is more attractive to mates

options.label: B
options.text: The melanic color combination is more resistant to disease

options.label: C
options.text: The non-melanic color combination helps the ladybugs avoid overheating

options.label: D
options.text: The melanic color combination is more common in the population

multiple-choice.question: What is one way humans can help species survive a changing world?

options.label: A
options.text: By identifying and setting aside critical climate refuges

options.label: B
options.text: By introducing non-native species to new ecosystems

options.label: C
options.text: By reducing the use of pesticides and herbicides

options.label: D
options.text: By increasing the amount of greenhouse gas emissions

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to preserve biodiversity on the planet?

options.label: B
options.text: Because it provides a source of food and medicine

options.label: C
options.text: Because it sustains us in many ways

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a moral obligation

title: Why are there so many insects? - Murry Gans

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of individual insects on Earth?
What percentage of all animals on Earth are insects?
What is one reason for the success of insects in terms of their adaptability and resilience?
What is an example of an insect that can survive in extreme environments?

options.label: A
options.text: Flat bark beetles can live at -40 degrees Fahrenheit

options.label: B
options.text: Sahara Desert ants can venture out when surface temperatures exceed 100 degrees

options.label: C
options.text: Some bumblebees can survive 10,000 feet above sea level

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above, but with more extreme conditions

multiple-choice.question: What is one benefit of an insect's small size?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes them more vulnerable to predators

options.label: B
options.text: It limits their ability to occupy different niches

options.label: C
options.text: It allows millions of insects to inhabit a small space

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of an insect that has built a niche around feces?

options.label: A
options.text: Flies lay their eggs in animal dung

options.label: B
options.text: Some beetles build large balls out of plant material

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of metamorphosis in insects?

options.label: B
options.text: To limit their ability to occupy different niches

options.label: C
options.text: To maximize the available resources in an ecosystem

options.label: D
options.text: To make them more vulnerable to predators

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of insect species undergo complete metamorphosis?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: By paralyzing live insects and laying eggs inside

multiple-choice.question: What can be concluded about the relationship between humans and insects on Earth?

options.label: D
options.text: Insects are irrelevant to the ecosystem

title: How ancient art influenced modern art - Felipe Galindo

multiple-choice.question: Who are some of the artists that pioneered the modern art movement and are now considered classics?

options.label: C
options.text: Art and artifacts from non-Western cultures, such as Africa and Polynesia

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: That it will be forgotten and have no impact on future artists

options.label: D
options.text: That it will be seen as a return to traditional art forms

title: Why do we love? A philosophical inquiry - Skye C. Cleary

multiple-choice.question: According to Plato, what is the primary reason humans love?

options.label: B
options.text: To become complete and whole again

options.label: D
options.text: To maintain the species and perpetuate the cycle of human drudgery

options.label: B
options.text: To escape our loneliness and engage more abundantly in life

options.label: C
options.text: To maintain the species and perpetuate the cycle of human drudgery

options.label: D
options.text: To reach an enlightened state of peace and clarity

multiple-choice.question: What is the central idea behind the Buddhist concept of love, as described in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Love is essential for human happiness and fulfillment

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: To avoid intimacy and emotional connection

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following philosophers believed that love is a means to achieve spiritual enlightenment?

options.label: C
options.text: To maintain the species and perpetuate the cycle of human drudgery

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following statements best summarizes the concept of love presented in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Love is a simple and straightforward emotion that brings happiness and fulfillment

options.label: B
options.text: Love is a complex and multifaceted emotion that can bring both joy and suffering

options.label: C
options.text: Love is a necessary evil for the continuation of the human species

options.label: D
options.text: Love is a means to achieve spiritual enlightenment

Which of the following philosophers believed that love is the desire to integrate with another and infuse our lives with meaning?

title: What outer space does to your body

multiple-choice.question: What happens to a person's spine in a zero-gravity environment?
Why does the heart change shape in space?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it has to pump harder to pull blood up from the feet

options.label: B
options.text: Because it's not having to pump as hard to pull blood up from the feet

options.label: C
options.text: Because the muscle walls become stronger

multiple-choice.question: What happens to bones in a zero-gravity environment?

options.label: C
options.text: They change shape and lose calcium

multiple-choice.question: Why do astronauts run on a treadmill in space?

options.label: B
options.text: To give loads into their bones and prevent atrophy

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the effects of changes in intracranial pressure in space?

options.label: C
options.text: Change in the shape of the eyeball

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason for the changes in the body in a zero-gravity environment?

options.label: A
options.text: The lack of oxygen in space

multiple-choice.question: If an astronaut's vision changes in space, what do they use to correct it?
What is the benefit of running on a treadmill in space, in terms of bone health?

options.label: B
options.text: It increases the risk of osteoporosis

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on bone health

multiple-choice.question: How does the absence of gravity affect the spine, and what is the result?

options.label: A
options.text: It compresses the spine, resulting in a decrease in height

options.label: B
options.text: It elongates the spine, resulting in an increase in height

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the spine

multiple-choice.question: Why do astronauts consider the changes in their bodies in space to be worthwhile?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are temporary and reversible

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are a small price to pay for the spirit of exploration

options.label: C
options.text: Because they have no impact on their daily lives

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are a necessary evil

title: History vs. Napoleon Bonaparte - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What significant event occurred in Europe in 1789?

options.label: C
options.text: The fall of the Roman Empire

options.label: D
options.text: The beginning of World War I

multiple-choice.question: What was a common misconception about Napolon Bonaparte's physical stature?

options.label: B
options.text: He was of average height for his time

multiple-choice.question: What was Napolon's role in the French Revolution?

options.label: A
options.text: He was a strong opponent of the revolution

options.label: B
options.text: He was a passive observer of the revolution

options.label: C
options.text: He was a young and successful military officer who supported the revolution

options.label: D
options.text: He was the leader of the revolution

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the group that unleashed a reign of terror on the population during the French Revolution?
How did Napolon derive his new powers?

options.label: B
options.text: Through a popular vote in the Consulate

multiple-choice.question: What was a significant achievement of Napolon's new constitution and legal code?

options.label: A
options.text: The abolition of freedom of religion

options.label: C
options.text: The establishment of equality before the law for all men

multiple-choice.question: What was a negative consequence of Napolon's rule?

options.text: The spread of democratic and liberal ideals across Europe

options.label: B
options.text: The abolition of slavery in the French colonies

options.label: C
options.text: The deprivation of women's rights and the reinstatement of slavery in the French colonies

options.label: D
options.text: The establishment of a stable and competent oligarchy

multiple-choice.question: Why did Napolon launch wars against other European powers?

options.label: A
options.text: To spread democratic and liberal ideals across Europe

options.label: B
options.text: To defend France against invading empires

options.label: C
options.text: To enforce a European-wide blockade of Britain

multiple-choice.question: What was a significant result of Napolon's wars?

options.label: A
options.text: The spread of democratic and liberal ideals across Europe

options.label: B
options.text: The rise of nationalism and the massive increase in army sizes

options.label: C
options.text: The establishment of a stable and competent oligarchy

multiple-choice.question: What ultimately led to Napolon's downfall?

options.label: A
options.text: His defeat in the Russian winter snows

options.label: C
options.text: His failed attempt to restore his empire

title: #TEDEdChat: Redefining Leadership | Drew Dudley | Leading with Lollipops |

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's primary concern about how people perceive leadership?

options.label: A
options.text: That it's too focused on personal gain

options.label: B
options.text: That it's too focused on grand, world-changing actions

options.label: C
options.text: That it's too focused on individual achievement

options.label: D
options.text: That it's too focused on teamwork

multiple-choice.question: What is the "lollipop moment" that the speaker describes?

options.label: A
options.text: A moment when someone gives you a lollipop

options.label: B
options.text: A moment when someone does something that makes your life better

options.label: C
options.text: A moment when you realize your true potential

options.label: D
options.text: A moment when you achieve great success

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, why do people often not acknowledge or thank others for their "lollipop moments"?

options.label: C
options.text: Because it's scary to think of ourselves as having that much power to impact others

options.label: D
options.text: Because they don't think it's important

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's call to action?

options.label: A
options.text: To become more arrogant and self-assured

options.label: B
options.text: To start celebrating birthdays more extravagantly

options.label: C
options.text: To get over our fear of how powerful we can be in each other's lives

options.label: D
options.text: To start giving out more lollipops

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker believe is the key to redefining leadership?

options.label: B
options.text: Focusing on creating and acknowledging "lollipop moments"

options.label: C
options.text: Focusing on personal gain and achievement

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the biggest impact we can have on someone's life?

options.label: A
options.text: Changing their understanding of the world

options.label: B
options.text: Giving them a lot of money

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker mean by "there is no world"?

options.label: B
options.text: That the world is too complex to understand

options.label: C
options.text: That there are six billion different understandings of the world

options.label: D
options.text: That the world is a mess

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what happens when we change one person's understanding of the world?

options.label: D
options.text: We make a big impact, but only on that one person

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's goal for redefining leadership?

options.label: A
options.text: To make leadership more exclusive and elite

options.label: B
options.text: To make leadership more focused on personal gain

options.label: C
options.text: To make leadership more about creating and acknowledging "lollipop moments"

options.label: D
options.text: To make leadership more about achieving great success

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker believe is the result of redefining leadership in this way?

options.label: A
options.text: That we will become more arrogant and self-assured

options.label: B
options.text: That we will start celebrating birthdays more extravagantly

options.label: D
options.text: That we will become more focused on personal gain

title: The beneficial bacteria that make delicious food - Erez Garty

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of yeast in bread-making?

options.label: C
options.text: To break down carbohydrates for energy

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the oxygen-independent pathway used by yeast to break down carbohydrates?
What happens to the small amounts of alcohol produced by yeast during bread-making?

options.label: A
options.text: They are retained in the bread

options.label: C
options.text: They are converted to carbon dioxide

options.label: D
options.text: They are consumed by other microorganisms

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of bacteria in wine production?

options.label: B
options.text: To convert ethanol into acetic acid

multiple-choice.question: What type of bacteria is responsible for turning wine into vinegar?
What is the purpose of adding rennet to milk during cheese production?

options.label: B
options.text: To convert lactose into lactic acid

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the enzyme naturally found in cows, goats, and other mammals that helps curdle milk?
What type of microorganism is responsible for the characteristic holes in Swiss cheese?
What is the result of the accumulation of carbon dioxide produced by yeast during bread-making?

options.label: B
options.text: The bread becomes softer and more sponge-like

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of mold in cheese production?

options.label: A
options.text: To convert lactose into lactic acid

options.label: D
options.text: To create a soft, white rind
